{{Infobox person | name = Randall Grahm | image = | alt = | caption = Randall at Bonny Doon Vineyard's Davenport tasting room | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|04|04}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], CA | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = Winemaker | known_for = [[Bonny Doon Vineyard]] }}
'''Randall Grahm''' is a Californian [[winemaker]] and the founder of [[Bonny Doon Vineyard]]. He is perhaps best known for his pioneering work with [[Rhône wine|Rhone varietals]] in California<ref>{{cite web|last1=Quist|first1=Cheryl|title=Rhone Rangers To Honor Randal Grahm with Lifetime Achievement Award|url=http://www.rhonerangers.org/pdf/Randall%20Grahm%20Award%20Press%20Release%20-%20Winemaker%20Dinner%203-22-2013.pdf|website=RhoneRangers.Org|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref> and for popularizing the use of [[alternative wine closures|screw caps]] on premium wines. He was an early proponent of transparent ingredient labeling on bottled wines,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Asimov|first1=Eric|title=Vintner With Nothing to Hide Finds That Few are Looking|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/10/dining/bonny-doon-vineyards-labeling-policy-draws-little-attention.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|website=The New York Times|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref> and has been a prominent advocate of [[terroir]]<ref =Smithsonian>{{cite web|last1=Bensen|first1=Amanda|title=Randall Grahm on Why Terroir Matters|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/randall-grahm-on-why-wines-terroir-matters-90904345/?no-ist|website=[[Smithsonian Mag]]|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref> wines and [[Biodynamic wine|biodynamic]] practice.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Fox|first1=Nick|title=The Wines Behind the Man|url=http://dinersjournal.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/04/21/the-wines-behind-the-man/|website=Blogs.NYTimes|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref>
==Biography==
Randall was born in [[Los Angeles]] in 1953 and attended [[University of California, Santa Cruz|UC Santa Cruz]] where he was "a permanent Liberal Arts major."<ref name=bio>{{cite web|last1=Grahm|first1=Randall|title=Biography|website=Bonny Doon Vineyard|url=https://www.bonnydoonvineyard.com/randall-grahm/biography/}}</ref> He eventually began working at the Wine Merchant in Beverly Hills sweeping floors. There he had the opportunity to taste great French wines and the experience turned him into "a complete and insufferable wine fanatic.<ref name=bio/> He returned to the [[University of California, Davis|University of California at Davis]] to complete a degree in [[Plant Sciences]] in 1979, where he developed a "single-minded obsession with [[Pinot Noir]]"<ref name=bio/>
With his family’s assistance, Grahm purchased property in [[Bonny Doon, California|Bonny Doon]], in the [[Santa Cruz Mountains]] where he was intent on producing "The Great American Pinot Noir." Although he initially had trouble with Pinot, he was encouraged by experimental batches of [[Rhône wine|Rhône varieties]], and he has been a tireless champion of Rhône grapes since the inaugural vintage of Le Cigare Volant in 1986. In 1989 Randall appeared on the cover of the [[Wine Spectator]], clad in blue polyester, as "The [[Rhone Rangers|Rhône Ranger]]," a moniker that has followed him ever since.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gibb|first1=Rebecca|title=Randall Grahm to Receive Lifetime Achievement Award|url=http://www.wine-searcher.com/m/2013/03/randall-grahm-to-receive-lifetime-achievement-award|website=wine-searcher.com}}</ref>
In 1991 Randall was added to the Who's Who of Cooking in America by Cook's Magazine,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Forster|first1=Laurie|title=Randall Grahm - Bonny Doon Vineyard|url=http://thewinecoach.com/randall-grahm-bonny-doon-vineyard/|website=The Wine Coach}}</ref> and in the same year [[Edward L. G. Bowell|Ted Bowell]] of the Lowell Observatory in northern Arizona named the "[[4934 Rhôneranger]]" asteroid in his honor. He was proclaimed Wine and Spirits Professional of the Year by the [[James Beard Foundation]] in 1994.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Zraly|first1=Kevin|title=Windows on the World Complete Wine Course 25th Anniv. Edition|date=September 29, 2009|publisher=Sterling|pages=315}}</ref>
Randall lectures frequently to wine societies and technical groups, and occasionally contributes "quixotically sincere" articles to wine journals.<ref name=bio/> His newsletters and articles were collected and published as the award-winning book, "''Been Doon So Long: A Randall Grahm Vinthology''" in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Grahm|first1=Randall|title=Been Doon So Long: A Randall Grahm Vinthology|url=http://www.beendoonsolong.com/book/|website=Been Doon So Long}}</ref> In 2010 [[The Culinary Institute of America]] inducted him into the Vintner’s Hall of Fame.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vintners Hall of Fame Inductees|url=http://www.ciaprochef.com/winestudies/events/vhf_inductees.html|website=The Culinary Institute of America|accessdate=1 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006102721/http://www.ciaprochef.com/winestudies/events/vhf_inductees.html|archivedate=6 October 2014|df=}}</ref> He currently lives in [[Santa Cruz, California|Santa Cruz]] with his partner Chinshu and their daughter, Amélie.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.bonnydoonvineyard.com Bonny Doon Vineyard, Home] *[http://www.beendoonsolong.com Been Doon So Long, Randall's blog]

{{Infobox person |name=Rashad Khalifa |image = |birth_date={{birth date|1935|11|19}} |birth_place=[[Egypt]] |death_date={{death date and age|1990|01|30 |1935|11|19}} |death_place=[[Tucson, Arizona]], [[United States|U.S.]] |nationality=Egyptian-American |occupation=[[Biochemist]] |known_for=United Submitters International |children=[[Sam Khalifa]] and Beth Bujarski }}
'''Rashad Khalifa''' ({{lang-ar|رشاد خليفة}}; November 19, 1935 – January 30, 1990) was an [[Egyptian American|Egyptian-American]] [[biochemist]], closely associated with the '''United Submitters International (USI)''', an offshoot reform Islamic group. His teachings, some of which depended on numerological analysis of the Quran, were opposed by [[Traditionalist Muslims]]. He was assassinated on January 31, 1990.
==Life==
Khalifa was born in Egypt on November 19, 1935. He obtained an honors degree from [[Ain Shams University]], Egypt, before he emigrated to the United States in 1959. He later earned a [[Master's Degree]] in [[biochemistry]] from [[Arizona State University]] and a Ph.D. from [[University of California]].<ref name="RK.life">{{Cite web|url=http://www.masjidtucson.org/submission/faq/rashad_khalifa_summary.html|title=Submission (Islam): Rashad Khalifa (Messenger of the Covenant), summary and facts|website=www.masjidtucson.org|access-date=2016-09-09}}</ref> He became a [[Naturalization|naturalized]] U.S. citizen and lived in [[Tucson, Arizona]].<ref name="RK.life"/> He was married to an American woman and they had a son and a daughter together.
Khalifa worked as a science adviser for the Libyan government for about one year, after which he worked as a chemist for the [[United Nations Industrial Development Organization]]. He next worked as a senior chemist in Arizona's State Office of Chemistry in 1980.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://archive.org/details/RashadKhalifa|title=Rashad Khalifa|last=Federal Bureau of Investigation}}</ref>
He was central to the founding of the USI.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Why the name change |author=Rashad Khalifa |date=September 1989 |journal=Submission Perspective |volume=57 |page=1 |url=http://www.quranalone.com/SP/57_1989_09.pdf }}</ref>
==Doctrine== Khalifa said that he was a [[Prophets and messengers in Islam|messenger of God]] but not a prophet, and that the archangel [[Gabriel]] "most assertively" told him that chapter 36, verse 3, of the Quran, "specifically" referred to him.<ref>[http://www.masjidtucson.org/quran/appendices/appendix2.html Appendix 2], Authorized English Version of the Quran, Rashad Khalifa, Ph.D.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masjidtucson.org/quran/appendices/appendix2.html|title=Appendix 2, God's Messenger of the Covenant|website=www.masjidtucson.org}}</ref> He coined the phrase "Final Testament" in reference to the Quran,<ref>''Quaranic Sciences'' - Page 277, Abbas Jaffer - 2009</ref> with his followers referring to him as "God's Messenger of the Covenant".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://submission.org/messenger/|title=Archived copy|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ZmxTU8Vt?url=http://submission.org/messenger/|archivedate=2008-08-03|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2008-08-03|df=}}</ref> Some Muslims objected to his interpretations, based on his claim that parts of the Quran were fabricated; precluding him from being a strict [[Quranism|Quranist]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://submission.org/two_false_verses_deeper_look.html|title=Two False verses; A Deeper Look {{!}} Submission.org - Your best source for Submission (Islam)|website=submission.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/42736348|title=Quran : the final testament|last=|first=|date=2000|publisher=Universal Unity|others=Khalifa, Rashad.|year=|isbn=1881893030|edition=Rev. ed. 2|location=Fremont, CA.|pages=Appendix 24|oclc=42736348}}</ref>
In his works, Khalifa claimed that the [[Quran]] contains a mathematical structure based on the number 19. Starting in 1968, Khalifa used computers to analyze the frequency of letters and words in the Quran, with his first book on the topic appearing in 1973.
Khalifa's research did not receive much attention in the [[Western world|West]]. In 1980, [[Martin Gardner]] mentioned it in ''[[Scientific American]]''.<ref>Gardner, Martin (1980), Mathematical Games, ''Scientific American'', September 1980, pp16–20.</ref> Gardner later wrote a more extensive and critical review of Khalifa and his work.<ref>"The numerology of Dr. Rashad Khalifa" - scientist, Martin Gardner, ''Skeptical Inquirer'', Sept-Oct, 1997</ref>
Khalifa's first published report in the [[Arab world]] appeared in the Egyptian magazine ''Akher Sa'a'', in January 1973.<ref>''Akher Sa'a magazine'', Egypt, January 24, 1973.</ref> Updates of his research were subsequently published by the same magazine later that year and again in 1975.<ref>''Akher Sa'a magazine'', Egypt, November 28, 1973.</ref><ref>''Akher Sa'a magazine'', Egypt, December 31, 1975.</ref>
==Criminal charges== In October 1979, Khalifa was accused in Tucson of sexual assault, sexual abuse, and sexual contact with a minor.<ref name=":0" /> The accuser, a 16-year-old-girl, testified at a hearing that Khalifa sexually molested her while supposedly recruiting her for a "United Nations" research project on the human aura.<ref name=":0" /> There was no physical evidence of intercourse found when the girl was examined at a local hospital, although Khalifa admitted to police that he had manipulated the girl's breast during his research.<ref name=":0" /> Justice of the Peace James P. West ruled there was probable cause to hold Khalifa for trial on the charges, due to his admission and "the circumstances under which Khalifa obtained the office".<ref name=":0">{{cite news |title=Tucson man faces trial in alleged rape of teen |publisher=Tucson Citizen |date=1979-10-06 |pages=2B |url=http://www.quransearch.com/rk_news_paper_article.htm }}</ref>
==Assassination== On January 31, 1990, Khalifa was found stabbed to death inside the Masjid (Mosque) of [[Tucson]] Arizona, his place of employment.<ref name=pipes>{{cite web|last1=Pipes|first1=Daniel|title=Finding Rashad Khalifa's Killer|url=http://www.danielpipes.org/blog/2009/04/finding-rashad-khalifas-killer|publisher=Daniel Pipes|accessdate=16 July 2014|date=Apr 28, 2009; updated Dec 24, 2012}}</ref> He was stabbed multiple times.
Nineteen years after the murder, on April 28, 2009, the Calgary Police Services of Canada arrested Glen Cusford Francis, a 52-year-old citizen of [[Trinidad and Tobago]], on suspicion of killing Rashad Khalifa.<ref name="Calgary police nab suspect">{{cite news|url=https://nationalpost.com/related/topics/story.html?id=1547368|title=Calgary police nab suspect in imam killing|last=Massinon|first=Stephane |date=April 30, 2009|work=National Post|publisher=The National Post Company|accessdate=2009-05-23}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Investigators in Tucson learned that Francis, who was going by the name Benjamin Phillips, had begun his studies under Khalifa in January 1990. Phillips disappeared shortly after the slaying,<ref name="Calgary police nab suspect" /> and was said to have left the country. An investigation revealed Phillips and Francis were the same man when the police analyzed fingerprints found in Phillips' apartment. A specialty unit of the Tucson Police Department progressed in its investigation in 2006 and in December 2008, and was able to use [[DNA testing]] on forensic evidence from the crime scene to tie Francis to the assassination.<ref name="Fugitive denied bail">{{cite news|url=https://vancouversun.com/Life/Fugitive+held+slaying+American+imam+denied+bail/1621967/story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090614091749/http://www.vancouversun.com/Life/Fugitive+held+slaying+American+imam+denied+bail/1621967/story.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=June 14, 2009|title=Fugitive held in slaying of American imam denied bail|last=Slade|first=Daryl|date=May 22, 2009|work=The Vancouver Sun|publisher=Canwest Publishing Inc.|accessdate=2009-05-23|df=}} </ref> In October 2009, a Canadian judge ordered Francis's extradition to the United States to face trial.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://cnews.canoe.ca/CNEWS/Crime/2009/10/17/11434296-sun.html|title=Calgary suspect closer to trial for U.S. murder|work=The Calgary Sun|last=Martin|first=Kevin|publisher=Sun Media|accessdate=2010-03-18|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707211142/http://cnews.canoe.ca/CNEWS/Crime/2009/10/17/11434296-sun.html|archive-date=2012-07-07|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The trial for the murder began on December 11, 2012. On December 19, the jury, after a three-hour deliberation, found Glen Francis guilty of first-degree murder and sentenced him to life in prison.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://calgaryherald.com/news/Calgarian+faces+life+sentence+1990+murder+controversial/7743101/story.html |title=Calgarian faces life sentence for 1990 murder of controversial U.S. imam |work=Calgary Herald |last=Komarnicki |first=Jamie |publisher=Postmedia Network |accessdate=2012-12-28 |archivedate=2012-12-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121228235110/http://www.calgaryherald.com/news/Calgarian+faces+life+sentence+1990+murder+controversial/7743101/story.html |df= }}</ref>
Prior to the Francis trial, James Williams, an alleged member of the [[Jamaat ul-Fuqra]] organization, was convicted of [[Conspiracy (criminal)|conspiracy]] in the slaying.<ref>Eric Anderson, "Slain Islamic leader was outspoken; Khalifa's teachings from Tucson angered Muslims worldwide", ''Denver Post'', 21 October 1993, p21.</ref> Williams disappeared on the day of his sentencing and could not be found.<ref>Dick Foster, "Extremist is 'not to be found'; Little hope held of finding Al-Fuqra fugitive", ''Rocky Mountain News'', 25 February 1994, p8.</ref> In 2000 Williams was apprehended attempting to re-enter the United States. and sentenced to serve 69 years in prison. His convictions were upheld on appeal by the [[Colorado Court of Appeals]] except for one count of [[forgery]].<ref>''People v. James D. Williams'', (Colo. App. 01CA0781, Aug. 7, 2003) (not selected for official publication)</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ago.state.co.us/press_detail.cfm?pressID=503 | title=Attorney General Announces Sentence | date=2001-03-16 | accessdate=2007-09-29 | publisher=Colorado Department of Law | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060929012047/http://www.ago.state.co.us/press_detail.cfm?pressID=503 | archive-date=2006-09-29 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref>
[[CBS News]] reported that Muslim extremist [[Wadih el-Hage]] was "connected to the 1990 stabbing death... El-Hage, who was indicted for lying about the case, called the assassination 'a good thing.'"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2001/10/26/attack/main316077.shtml | title=Terrorists Take To Arizona | date=2001-10-26 | accessdate=2007-09-29 | publisher=CBS Worldwide Inc | quote=El-Hage has also been connected to the 1990 stabbing death of a Tucson mosque leader. Rashad Khalifa was hated by Muslim extremists opposed to his teachings. El-Hage, who was indicted for lying about the case, called the assassination "a good thing."}}</ref> If he was involved, Khalifa would be possibly the first American to be killed by an operative of [[Al Qaeda]] in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://s3.amazonaws.com/911timeline/2001/arizonarepublic092801.html|title=Arizona Was Home to bin Laden ''Sleeper Cell''|website=s3.amazonaws.com}}</ref>
==Bibliography== * ''Miracle of the Quran: Significance of the Mysterious Alphabets'', Islamic Productions, St. Louis, Missouri, 1973. * ''The Computer Speaks: God's Message to the World'', Renaissance Productions, Tucson, Arizona, 1981. * ''Qur'an: The Final Scripture'', Islamic Productions, Tucson, Arizona, 1981. * ''Qur'an: Visual Presentation of the Miracle'', Islamic Productions, Tucson, Arizona, 1982. * ''Qur'an, Hadith and Islam'', Islamic Productions, Tucson, Arizona, 1982. * ''Qur'an: The Final Testament'', Islamic Productions, Tucson, Arizona, 1989.

'''Richard Joel Wassersug''' (Born April 13, 1946) was an Honorary [[professor]] in the Department of Cellular and Physiological Sciences at the [[University of British Columbia]]. He was also an adjunct professor in the Department of Medical Neuroscience at [[Dalhousie University]] with a cross appointment in the Department of [[Psychology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://anatomy.medicine.dal.ca/deptmembs.htm |title=Dalhousie Anatomy and Neurobiology Faculty and Administration |publisher=Anatomy.medicine.dal.ca |accessdate=2011-03-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://psychology.dal.ca/People/Cross-Appointed_Facu.php |title=Cross-Appointed Faculty - Department of Psychology |publisher=Psychology.dal.ca |date=2010-10-14 |accessdate=2011-03-12}}</ref> In additions, he is an adjunct professor at The Australian Research Centre in Sex, Health & Society (ARCSHS), [[La Trobe University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latrobe.edu.au/arcshs/research-profiles/view-profile?uname=RWassersug |title=Staff profile, La Trobe University |publisher=Latrobe.edu.au |date=2010-08-12 |accessdate=2011-03-12}}</ref>
==Biography==
Wassersug received his [[Bachelor of Arts]] from [[Tufts University]] in [[geology]] and biology in 1967 and his [[PhD]] from the [[University of Chicago]] in [[Evolutionary Biology]] in 1973. He became a professor in the Dalhousie University’s Department of Anatomy and Neurobiology in 1986 and Honorary Associate Professor in Dalhousie University’s School of Physiotherapy in 1989. In 2010 was an honorary visiting professor at the Australian Research Centre in Sex, Health and Society, at La Trobe University.<ref>[http://anatomy.medicine.dal.ca/Wassersug/currentresearch.html]{{self-published inline|date=November 2010}}</ref>
Wassersug is an outspoken communicator of scientific ideas, having served on [[CBC Radio]]’s Maritime Noon Science Panel and as a columnist on The Canadian Discovery Channel's [[Daily Planet (TV series)]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/maritimenoon/phone-in-regulars.html |title=Maritime Noon | Phone-In Regulars |publisher=CBC.ca |date=2009-06-25 |accessdate=2011-03-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Ingram |first=Jay |year=2010 |title=Daily Planet: The Ultimate Book of Everyday Science |publisher=Penguin Canada |page=145 |isbn=978-0-14-317786-9}}</ref>
==Research==
The majority of his scientific career has been spent studying the functional [[morphology (biology)|morphology]] and behavior of [[anuran]] [[larvae]]. He has published over 150 peer-reviewed papers on these animals. Wassersug’s more recent work focuses on [[prostate cancer]] and the psychology of [[androgen]] deprivation.<ref>[http://anatomy.medicine.dal.ca/wassersug/currentresearch.html]{{self-published inline|date=November 2010}}</ref>
Wassersug has received funding for his research from the [[Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council]], the [[Canadian Institutes of Health Research]], Prostate Cancer Canada, the Prostate Cancer Foundation of British Columbia, Nova Scotia Health Research Foundation, the [[Canadian Space Agency]], [[Parks Canada]], and the Dalhousie Medical Research Foundation.<ref>[http://anatomy.medicine.dal.ca/wassersug/RichardWassersugCV.html]{{self-published inline|date=November 2010}}</ref>
==Awards==
Wassersug received the Science Communication Award from the [[Atlantic Provinces]] Council on the Sciences in 2001.<ref>Atlantic Provinces Council on the Sciences Biennial Report April 1, 2001 – March 31, 2003 http://apics.dal.ca/members/Biennial%20Report%20Apr01-Mar03.pdf</ref> He was also named a Science Champion during the Discovery Awards for Science and Technology in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dalnews.dal.ca/2002/12/11/people.shtml |title=People |publisher=dalnews.dal.ca |date=2002-12-11 |accessdate=2011-03-12}}</ref>
He won an [[Ig Nobel Prize]] in 2000 for his firsthand report, "On the Comparative Palatability of Some Dry-Season [[Tadpoles]] from [[Costa Rica]]".<ref>http://improbable.com/ig/winners/#ig2000</ref>

'''Airling Robin Hanbury-Tenison''' [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]], DL, Dsc, Dhc, MA, FLS, [[FRGS]] (born 7 May 1936)<ref>{{Cite book|title=Who's Who 2016 |publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref> is an explorer based in [[Cornwall]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/celebrity-interviews/Robin-Hanbury-Tenisons-Travelling-Life/|title=Robin Hanbury-Tenison's Travelling Life|last=|first=|date=|publisher=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> He is President of the charity [[Survival International]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.survivalinternational.org/|title=Survival International|date=|publisher=}}</ref> and was previously Chief Executive of The Countryside Alliance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.countryside-alliance.org/|title=Countryside Alliance|last=|first=|date=|publisher=}}</ref>
==Life==
Hanbury-Tenison grew up on an [[Anglo-Irish]] estate in [[County Monaghan]] in Ireland, the youngest of five children. In 1959, he married [[Marika Hanbury-Tenison|Marika Hopkinson]]. She became well known for her cookery books.<ref name=Marika1972>Hanbury Tenison, M. ''Deep-Freeze Cookery''. 2nd edition. London. Pan Books, 1972, p. i.</ref> They had two children, Lucy (b. 1960) and Rupert (b. 1970).<ref name=CV>[http://www.cabilla.co.uk/robinsbooks/documents/26.html Robin Hanbury-Tenison Curriculum Vitae]</ref> Marika died in 1982.
Hanbury-Tenison and his second wife Louella (née Williams) own a 14th century farmhouse, Cabilla Manor, on [[Bodmin Moor]], which is both their home and a bed and breakfast business. They have a son, Merlin (b. 1985).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.burkespeerage.com/distinguishedFamilies_Sudeley.php|title=Robin Hanbury-Tenison|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Burke's Peerage}}</ref>
In 1957 Hanbury-Tenison was the first person to travel overland by jeep from London to Sri Lanka (Ceylon).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wonderlancer.com/socialogue/robin-hanbury-tenison-survival-international/|title= – Feature|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=WonderLancer}}</ref> In 1958 he and Richard Mason became the first to cross South America overland at its widest point.<ref name="Geographical">{{cite web | url=http://www.geographical.co.uk/Magazine/People/Robin_Hanbury-Tenison_-_November_2006.html | title=Robin Hanbury-Tenison | publisher=Geographical | date=November 2006 | author=Smith, Nick}}</ref> In 1964–65 he made the first river crossing of S America from north to south from the Orinoco to Buenos Aires (at first with Sebastian Snow). In 1968 he took part in the [[Geographical (magazine)|Geographical Magazine]] Amazonas Expedition by Hovercraft from Manaus to Trinidad. Discussions with the [[ethnobotany|ethnobotanist]] [[Conrad Gorinsky]] led to the foundation of the charity [[Survival International]].<ref>{{cite book | title=Worlds Apart: An Explorer's Life | publisher=Arrow Books | author=Hanbury-Tenison, Robin | year=1991 | pages = 115–128}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.businessdestinations.com/bd-portrait/robin-hanbury-tenison-the-tale-of-the-explorer-and-philanthropist/|title=Survival|last=|first=|date=|website=Business Destinations}}</ref> In 1971, as Chairman of Survival (and with Marika), he visited 33 Indian tribes in Brazil at the invitation of the Brazilian government and reported on their condition. In 1977–78 he led the [[Royal Geographical Society]]'s [[Gunung Mulu National Park|Gunung Mulu]] expedition to [[Sarawak]], the Society's largest expedition at that time, taking 115 scientists into the [[rainforest]] for 15 months.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rgs.org/NR/rdonlyres/B53CB457-9FB6-4F12-B37D-CEFE69519B20/0/MuluBibliography.pdf|title=Mulu Park Expedition|last=|first=|date=|publisher=[[Royal Geographical Society]]}}</ref>
Since 1960 Hanbury-Tenison has farmed over 2000 acres of hill farm on Bodmin Moor in Cornwall with sheep and cattle, diversified with [[Angora goat]]s, [[red deer]] and [[wild boar]] from Russia, and later farming energy from wind, solar, water and biomass.{{cn|date=November 2018}}
In 1982 and 1983 he organised Capital Radio's Venture Days in Battersea Park. From 1995 to 1998 he was CEO of the [[British Field Sports Society]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/wildlife-chief-quits-1587029.html|title=BFSS|last=|first=|date=|publisher=The Independent}}</ref> now the [[Countryside Alliance]]. He organised the Countryside Rally, which brought 130,000 people to Hyde Park in July 1997, and the Countryside March when 300,000 marched through London in 1998.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1998/mar/03/listening-to-the-countryside|title=Countryside March Reference |last=|first=|date=|publisher=Hansard}}</ref>
In 2015–16 he celebrated his 80th year by undertaking eight challenges, starting with the London Marathon, which raised over £80,000 for [[Survival International]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cornwall-living.co.uk/clm-38/in-conversation-with-robin-hanbury-tenison/|title=80th Year|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Cornwall Living|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.survivalinternational.org/news/10688|title=8 Challenges|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Survival International}}</ref>
==Awards and achievements== * 1961 RGS [[Ness Award]] * 1965–95 Commissioner of Income Tax * 1968–82 RGS Council Member, 1982–86 Vice President * 1969–81 Co-founder and Chairman of [[Survival International]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p009mgyz|title=Desert Island Discs|date=1984|publisher=BBC}}</ref> * 1971 [[Winston Churchill Memorial]] Fellow * 1979 [[Gold Medal (RGS)|RGS Patron's Gold Medal]] * 1980 Winner Krug Award for Excellence * 1981 President of [[Survival International]] * 1981 [[Order of the British Empire]] * 1984–2015 President Camel Valley and Bodmin Moor Protection Society * 1988–95 President Cornwall Wildlife Trust * 1998 Farmers Club Cup for outstanding contribution to farming, agriculture and the countryside * 1999 Chairman Friends of Conservation * 1999 International Council for Game and Wildlife Conservation Personality of the Year * 2001 RSGS [[Mungo Park Medal]] * 2000 Pio Manzu Medal (Italy) * 2000 CLA Contribution to the Countryside Award * 2001-5 President Rain Forest Club * 2003 Patron of the Countryside Alliance * 2003–2011 Deputy Lieutenant for the County of Cornwall * 2009 President Cornwall Red Squirrel Project * 2012 Best Large Scale Renewable Energy Scheme in Cornwall Award for Cabilla Manor * 2013 Exhibition of photographs of tribal people and places, National Theatre<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nickyakehurst.com/photographers/RobinHanburyTenison/index.html|title=National Theatre Exhibition|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Akehurst Creative Management|access-date=}}</ref> * 2014 Honorary Consul for Kosovo (Cornwall) <!--Founder member of FWAG, Ambassador for the Westcountry Development Corporation. -->
==Books== <!--in date order--> * ''The Rough and the Smooth (1969)'' * ''A Question of Survival for the Indians of Brazil (1973)'' * ''A Pattern of Peoples: A Journey Among the Tribes of Indonesia's Outer Islands (1975)'' * ''Mulu: Rain Forest (1980)'' * ''Aborigines of the Amazon Rain Forest (Peoples of the Wild) (1982)'' * ''Worlds Apart: An Explorer's Life (1984)'' * ''White Horses over France: From the Camargue to Cornwall (1985)''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.horsetravelbooks.com/rht.htm|title=Horse Travels – Long Distance Riding|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=}}</ref> * ''A Ride Along the Great Wall (1987)'' * ''Fragile Eden: A Ride Through New Zealand (1989)'' * ''Spanish Pilgrimage: A Canter to St. James (1990)'' * ''The Oxford Book of Exploration (1993)'' * ''Mysterious China (1995)'' * ''Chinese Adventure: A Ride Along the Great Wall (2004)'' * ''Worlds Within: Reflections in the Sand (2005)'' * ''The Seventy Great Journeys in History (2006)'' * ''Land of Eagles: Riding Through Europe's Forgotten Country (2009)''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thelongridersguild.com/rht.htm|title=The Long Riders Guild – Albania|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=}}</ref> * ''The Great Explorers (2010)''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/jan/15/great-explorers-hanbury-tenison-review|title=Book Review|last=|first=|date=|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> * ''The Modern Explorers, with Robert Twigger (2013)'' * ''Echoes of a Vanished World: A Traveller's Lifetime in Pictures (2013)'' * ''Beauty Freely Given: A Universal Truth: Artifacts from the Collection of Robin Hanbury-Tenison, with Christopher John Bowden (2013)'' * ''Into Eden (2017)''
===For children<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.penguin.co.uk/authors/robin-hanbury-tenison/1030056/|title=Penguin Children's Books|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Penguin}}</ref>=== * ''Jake's Escape'' (1996) * ''Jake's Treasure'' (1997) * ''Jake's Safari'' (1998)
==Films== * ''A Time for Survival''. Westward (1972) * ''Mysteries of the Green Mountain''. BBC (1978) * ''Antiques at Home''. BBC (1984) * ''White Horses over France''. BBC/FR3 (1985) * ''Great Wall of China'' (1987) * ''Odyssey'' series, presenter BBC (1988) * ''Siberian Tigers'' (1994) * ''Collector's Lot'' BBC (1998) * ''The Lost World of Mulu''. C4 (1999) * ''Reflections in the Sand''. Discovery (2000) * ''Testament''. Carlton (2000)
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.robinsbooks.co.uk Website] * [http://www.cabilla.co.uk Cabilla Manor Website] * [http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/explorer-robin-hanbury-tenison-s-year-epic/story-26379216-detail/story.html WMN 8 Challenges Article]

'''Runcie C. W. Chidebe''' (born 26 December 1985) is a young [[Nigerian]] [[cancer]] control [[advocate]] and [[Social entrepreneurship|social entrepreneur]]. He is the founder and executive director <ref>{{cite web|last1=UICC|title=SPARC grant awardees - Meet Runcie from Nigeria|url=http://www.uicc.org/sparc-grant-awardees-meet-runcie-nigeria|website=www.uicc.org|publisher=Union for International Cancer Control (UICC)|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=Runcie>{{cite news|title=Exclusive Interview with Runcie Chidebe|url=http://medqhealthmagazine.com/exclusive-interview-runcie-chidebe/|accessdate=4 October 2016|publisher=MED-Q Health Magazine|date=13 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=BellaNaija.com|title=Meet these Young Change Makers! All You Need to Know about the LEAP Africa 2015/2016 SIPA Fellows|url=https://www.bellanaija.com/2016/04/meet-these-young-change-makers-all-you-need-to-know-about-the-leap-africa-20152016-sipa-fellows/|website=BellaNaija.com|publisher=BellaNaija.com|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=CIVICUS|first1=WorldAlliance|title=Project Pink Blue: Winner, Nelson Mandela Graça Machel Innovation Awards. Category: Organization|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0Yy55qPxQms|website=YouTube|date=25 November 2014|accessdate=18 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Unah|first1=Linus|title='I thought cancer was a disease for the elderly': tackling Nigeria's 80% mortality rate|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2017/mar/20/nigeria-cancer-mortality-rate-addressed-ngo|accessdate=18 July 2017|agency=The Guardian|publisher=The Guardian|date=20 March 2017}}</ref> of Project PINK BLUE- Health & Psychological Trust Centre, a Nigerian cancer non-profit organization that is engaged in cancer awareness, free cancer screenings, advocacy, patient navigation and support to indigent women battling with cancer.<ref>{{cite web|last1=U.S. Department of State|first1=INTERNATIONAL EXCHANGE ALUMNI|title=A Champion for Cancer Care in Nigeria|url=https://alumni.state.gov/alumni-story/champion-cancer-care-nigeria|website=Alumni.State.Gov|publisher=Alumni|accessdate=18 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=I wasn’t really outstanding in secondary school, but I chose to be better –Chidebe, winner, World Economic Forum for Africa award 2014|url=http://transparentnigeria.com/news_entries/1771/I-wasn%E2%80%99t-really-outstanding-in-secondary-school,-but-I-chose-to-be-better-%E2%80%93Chidebe,-winner,-World-Economic-Forum-for-Africa-award-2014|accessdate=4 October 2016|publisher=Transparent Nigeria|date=26 September 2014}}</ref> He is one of the 1000 winners of Tony Elumelu Entrepreneurship Programme(TEEP) in 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=#TEEP2015 Winner Feature: Runcie Chidebe|url=http://www.areedi.com/2015/04/teep2015-winner-feature-runcie-chidebe/|accessdate=4 October 2016|publisher=Areedi|date=8 April 2015}}</ref> An alumnus of the [[United States Department of State]] [https://eca.state.gov/ivlp International Visitor Leadership Program (IVLP)] <ref>{{cite web|last1=Global|first1=Ties US|title=NIGERIAN NURSES LEARN CANCER PATIENT CARE|url=http://www.globaltiesus.org/news/international-exchange-in-the-news/543-nigerian-nurses-learn-cancer-patient-care|website=Global Ties|publisher=Global Ties|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=United States Diplomatic Mission|title=U.S. Fulbright Specialist Trains 34 Nigerian Nurses in Cancer Patient Care (November 29, 2016)|url=https://nigeria.usembassy.gov/pr_11292016.html|website=Nigeria US Embassy|publisher=U.S. Embassy in Nigeria|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref>
== Early life and family == Chidebe was born on 26 December 1985 in Talata Mafara, [[Zamfara State]] to Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Chidebe. He is the last of five sons. He hails from [[Oba, Anambra|Oba]], [[Idemili South]] Local Government Area of [[Anambra state]].<ref name=Runcie/>
== Educational background == Chidebe attended Government Secondary School, Gwarimpa, Abuja and later obtained Diploma in [[Social work|Social Work]] with distinctions and bachelor's degree in [[Psychology]], [[Sociology]] & [[Anthropology]], both from [[University of Nigeria, Nsukka]] where he emerged as the 2011/2012 best graduating student from his department.<ref name=Runcie/><ref>{{cite news|title=EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW WITH RUNCIE CHIDEBE|url=http://medqhealthmagazine.com/exclusive-interview-runcie-chidebe/|accessdate=16 October 2016|publisher=MedQmag|date=13 July 2016}}</ref> He also has a certificate on Entrepreneurship from [http://www.edc.edu.ng Enterprise Development Centre] in 2015.
== Career and work == During his [[National Youth Service Corps]] (NYSC) in 2013 at Abuja, he carried out a community development project on breast cancer campaign through which he provided free screening and counseling to indigent women in Kabusa, Kuje, and Kubwa. The impact of his NYSC project propelled him to establish Project PINK BLUE.<ref name=Runcie/> Over 700 women have directly benefited from his free cancer screening while more than a million has been reached through his campaigns.<ref name=PPB>{{cite web|title=Runcie C.W. Chidebe's Page|url=http://ypchronic.org/profile/RuncieCWChidebe|website=YP-CDN|publisher=Young Professionals Chronic Disease Network|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref> A champion of cancer research and better patient care, Runcie Chidebe has demonstrated to his native Nigeria the importance of volunteerism and collective action for causes that benefit society.<ref>{{cite web|last1=U.S. Department of State|first1=International Exchange Alumni|title=A Champion for Cancer Care in Nigeria|url=https://alumni.state.gov/alumni-story/champion-cancer-care-nigeria|website=Alumni.State.Gove|publisher=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=18 July 2017}}</ref>
== Advocacy and Youth Engagement == Chidebe has called on Nigeria's Federal Government to make national health a priority;<ref>{{cite news|last1=Konbini|first1=Nescafe|title=How Runcie Chidebe Is Helping Phase Out Late Diagnosis Of Cancer In Africa|url=http://www.konbini.com/ng/inspiration/runcie-chidebe/|accessdate=18 July 2017|agency=Konbini|publisher=Konbini|date=23 May 2017}}</ref> to save her women, men and children dying of cancer. By establishing the National Agency on Cancer Control, there will be more awareness and significant reduction in the prevalence of cancer in Nigeria.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Business|first1=Day|title=NGO seeks establishment of National Cancer Control Agency|url=https://www.businessdayonline.com/ngo-seeks-establishment-national-cancer-control-agency/|website=Business Day Online|publisher=Business Day|accessdate=18 July 2017}}</ref> Chidebe has recently co-authored an article on Advancing access and equity: the vision of a new generation in cancer control.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=|first1=Oncology|title=Advancing access and equity: the vision of a new generation in cancer control|journal=The Lancet Oncology|date=February 2017|volume= 18|issue= 2|pages=172–175|doi=10.1016/S1470-2045(17)30041-4|url=http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanonc/article/PIIS1470-2045(17)30041-4/abstract|accessdate=18 July 2017}}</ref>
